linkTarget.anchoringText: The Golfo San Jorge Basin (CGSJ), located in Central Patagonia (Figure 1), can be defined as an intracratonic Basin, extensional, elongated in an E-W direction, bounded by the Macizo Nord Patag√≥nico to the North and the Deseado Region to the south. The main sedimentary fill of the basin was produced during the end of the rifting stages, in the late Jurassic, and in the sag stages in the Cretaceous Period, and finished with an Atlantic Tertiary marine transgression.

The study area is located within the Field Los Perales - Las Mesetas (LP-LM), on the northern flank of the Santa Cruz Province, about 45 km northwest of Las Heras city. The selected study zone contemplates an area of 2300 hectares. Figure 2 shows Los Perales Field and the study zone. There are 260 wells drilled in this area.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Los Perales Field and study zone

formatted-caption.caption-text: Los Perales Field and study zone

linkTarget.anchoringText: Low sinuosity fluvial systems, mud flats and shallow lakes have been observed. The geometry of these bodies corresponds to lobes and sheets with important volcaniclastic participation. Vertical wells cross this formation at the range of 900 to 1400 MBBP. It consist of multilayer reservoirs of 1 to 12 layers per production level, with an average of 4 levels per well. The productive layers correspond to lenses and filled canal. The thicknesses vary between 1 to 12 meters (average 3 to 4 m). The width of the channels varies between 600 and 1500 meters. Figure 3 shows the stratigraphic sequence of the region. Figure 4 shows a layer corresponding to one of the channels identified.

Low sinuosity fluvial systems, mud flats and shallow lakes have been observed. The geometry of these bodies corresponds to lobes and sheets with important volcaniclastic participation. Vertical wells cross this formation at the range of 900 to 1400 MBBP. It consist of multilayer reservoirs of 1 to 12 layers per production level, with an average of 4 levels per well. The productive layers correspond to lenses and filled canal. The thicknesses vary between 1 to 12 meters (average 3 to 4 m). The width of the channels varies between 600 and 1500 meters. Figure 3 shows the stratigraphic sequence of the region. Figure 4 shows a layer corresponding to one of the channels identified.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Sismic cross section of La Itala.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sismic cross section of La Itala.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Then the scaling was performed to integrate it into the chosen grid, and the variable was modeled using the Sequential Indicator Simulation algorithm using a Vertical Proportion Curve (VPC). This curve is the sum of the vertical distribution of the different facies (sand / clay) based on the modeling of the different levels. Once the curve was created, we were able to quickly visualize the different sedimentological cycles and adjust the main horizons of the column (Figure 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Facies model and vertical proportion curve

formatted-caption.caption-text: Facies model and vertical proportion curve

linkTarget.anchoringText: The porosity (Phie) was modeled using a cut-off of 12% to distinguish the reservoir levels from the non-reservoir. More than 400 independent hydraulic units were defined in the model throughout the column (Figure 6a and Figure 6b).

The porosity (Phie) was modeled using a cut-off of 12% to distinguish the reservoir levels from the non-reservoir. More than 400 independent hydraulic units were defined in the model throughout the column (Figure 6a and Figure 6b).

As part of the verification, correlated layers of the 2D model were incorporated into the 3D model. The layers were included as surfaces represented by the top of the layers. In this way, it was possible to see how this new methodology is able to reproduce the layers identified with the layer-by-layer correlation. The figure 7 shows this comparison.

In each layer to layer map, the results of the completion test for each well are asigned with a special symbolism. If it were the case that the coat was not opened in some well to assign a fluid is used profile petrophysical evaluation. Contacts are plotted with the essays and forecasts dumps on the map. The figure 8 shows a map of one of the layers with trials and contacts. These are the values that are used to generate the 290 regions in the model. Each, with an independently defined contact.

These equations can be used to carry out the construction of the average real curves once the-standards. Curves normalized to the permeabilities of water and oil, can be expressed as a function of: the saturation of water standard Sw*, and the relationship (K/œï) NOBP. This simplifies the obtaining of curves corresponding to a zone with a relationship (K/œï) NOBP different, given that is not necessary to perform the interpolation between the curves ends. (Figure 9)

In order to populate the model with the each corresponding permeability values (PERMX, PERMY), the same core data were used, making a K vs. Phi cross plot. This relationship between the core permeability vs. core porosity values was used to calculate their permeability equivalence as a function of profile porosity values (Figure 10).

To carry out the historical adjustment of the model, the production history of the 260 wells was loaded. The 22 years of oil, water and gas production of each of the wells were charged monthly. Water injection began in 2002 (Figure 11). This storical inyection was loaded to the simulator too. This information is the basis for running the first history run. The wells were controlled by liquid. This control allows the model to produce the total liquid of the well in order to control the volumes and thus the behavior of the pressure.

Against this drawback is that we decided to try the streamlines. Response times were amazing. Simulation time was reduced to 2.5 hours. Faced with this and before continuing with the history matching with this methodology we decided to run some simple checks. Figure 12 shows both run logs with time laps.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Run time comparison ‚Äì Left numerical simulation ‚Äì Right Streamline.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Run time comparison ‚Äì Left numerical simulation ‚Äì Right Streamline.

linkTarget.anchoringText: To confirm the feasibility of using streamlines as adjustment methodology, we first performed 4 runs with the traditional simulation by making some changes in boxes of different layers. Those same models also ran them with Streamlines and we overlap the results. As you can see in Figure 13 there is no difference between a method and another it comes to global production. Figure 14a and Figure 14b also samples two wells production which does not show the difference also.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: First runs comparisons Field level ‚Äì Stream line (circle) vs. numerical sim (x) ‚Äì Continued history.

formatted-caption.caption-text: First runs comparisons Field level ‚Äì Stream line (circle) vs. numerical sim (x) ‚Äì Continued history.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Once the reservoir level adjustment was achieved (Figure 15), the well-to-well adjustment was continued. Following the same methodology of the adjustment at field level, but now located in the areas bordering each well. Well was worked well to try to adjust its history of production of water and oil. It must be taken into account that each well has on average between 5 and 15 productive levels. Each of them hydraulically independent of each other.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Last simulation History match ‚Äì Field level

formatted-caption.caption-text: Last simulation History match ‚Äì Field level

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figures. 16a, 16b and 16c shows good and regular adjustments per well. For this report only three wells are presented. Two considered with a good fit in oil and water. Anotherone, where the adjustment is not so good and requires more work. It is possible to see how in all cases of good fit the product curve of the simulation represents very well the peaks of production. In the case of regular adjustments it is seen that the problem is saturation. The total liquid fits well, but not water and oil. Where one is abundant, the other is scarce, compensating for the volumes. This should be layered by differences in initial saturations.

Figures. 16a, 16b and 16c shows good and regular adjustments per well. For this report only three wells are presented. Two considered with a good fit in oil and water. Anotherone, where the adjustment is not so good and requires more work. It is possible to see how in all cases of good fit the product curve of the simulation represents very well the peaks of production. In the case of regular adjustments it is seen that the problem is saturation. The total liquid fits well, but not water and oil. Where one is abundant, the other is scarce, compensating for the volumes. This should be layered by differences in initial saturations.

Figures. 16a, 16b and 16c shows good and regular adjustments per well. For this report only three wells are presented. Two considered with a good fit in oil and water. Anotherone, where the adjustment is not so good and requires more work. It is possible to see how in all cases of good fit the product curve of the simulation represents very well the peaks of production. In the case of regular adjustments it is seen that the problem is saturation. The total liquid fits well, but not water and oil. Where one is abundant, the other is scarce, compensating for the volumes. This should be layered by differences in initial saturations.

As mentiones before, due to the size of the static model, the number of active cells and the number of years of production history, it was decided to work the dynamic model with Streamlines. The traditional dynamic simulation, to run the 22 years of history, demanded 12 hours. The model running with flow lines only 2.5 hours. For this reason, all historical adjustment runs were performed with this methodology (Figure 17).

Moreover, the modeling presented in this paper will allow us to determine non-swept zones with initial saturation (Figure 18), wellbore production, and deficiencies in sweeping efficiency. Points that are not possible to be analyzed with the current way of studying. Having achieved the historical adjustment encourages us to continue advancing with this methodology.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: First and last time step showing how Sw (water saturation) changed through time.

formatted-caption.caption-text: First and last time step showing how Sw (water saturation) changed through time.
